title: Borel isomorphism
text:
In mathematics, a Borel isomorphism is a measurable bijective function between two measurable <a href="Borel%20set">standard Borel</a> spaces. By <a href="analytic%20set">Souslin's theorem</a> in standard Borel spaces (a set that is both <a href="Analytic%20set">analytic</a> and <a href="coanalytic">coanalytic</a> is necessarily Borel), the inverse of any such measurable bijective function is also measurable. Borel isomorphisms are closed under composition and under taking of inverses. The set of Borel isomorphisms from a space to itself clearly forms a <a href="group%20%28mathematics%29">group</a> under composition. Borel isomorphisms on standard Borel spaces are analogous to <a href="homeomorphism">homeomorphism</a>s on <a href="topological%20space">topological space</a>s: both are bijective and closed under composition, and a homeomorphism and its inverse are both <a href="Continuity%20%28topology%29">continuous</a>, instead of both being only Borel measurable.
Borel space.
A <a href="measurable%20space">measurable space</a> that is Borel isomorphic to a measurable subset of the real numbers is called a Borel space.
